articles.headline: New Suitor for Exchange in Chicago
articles.snippet: Intercontinental Exchange made a $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
articles.abstract: Intercontinental Exchange made a $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, March 15 — The Intercontinental Exchange surprised financial markets Thursday by making an unsolicited $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

articles.headline: Green Energy Enthusiasts Are Also Betting on Fossil Fuels
articles.snippet: Some technology investors that portray themselves as green-friendly are inconsistent with their marketing message.
articles.abstract: Some technology investors that portray themselves as green-friendly are inconsistent with their marketing message.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s technology investors have taken to the ramparts, threatening to tear down the oil and gas industries’ dominance with innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind.

articles.headline: History of Hernia Patch Raises Questions on Implant Recalls
articles.snippet: Some major manufacturers, while contending that they carefully monitor product safety, are not as rigorous as they should be.
articles.abstract: Some major manufacturers, while contending that they carefully monitor product safety, are not as rigorous as they should be.
articles.lead_paragraph: How do makers of implanted medical devices react when one of their products starts breaking?

articles.headline: A Lawyer Like a Hurricane
articles.snippet: Richard F. Scruggs, the lawyer representing homeowners affected by Hurricane Katrina, has turned the case into a nightmare for the insurance industry.
articles.abstract: Richard F. Scruggs, the lawyer representing homeowners affected by Hurricane Katrina, has turned the case into a nightmare for the insurance industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASCAGOULA, Miss. — Richard F. Scruggs, one of the country’s most successful trial lawyers, made his first fortune in a case that hit close to home. He sued asbestos makers on behalf of workers at the shipyard in his hometown, Pascagoula, who had developed lung diseases. He made his second fortune with lawsuits against the tobacco industry, coming up with a winning legal strategy in Mississippi that he then applied nationwide.

articles.headline: New Face of Jihad Vows Attacks
articles.snippet: A fugitive Palestinian has formed a new militant Islamic organization called Fatah al Islam.
articles.abstract: A fugitive Palestinian has formed a new militant Islamic organization called Fatah al Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Lebanon — Deep in a violent and lawless slum just north of this coastal city, 12 men whose faces were shrouded by scarves drilled with Kalashnikovs.
articles.byline: By Souad Mekhennet and Michael Moss

articles.headline: Far From Inevitable, McCain Retunes 2008 Engine
articles.snippet: After an uneasy start to his campaign, Senator John McCain is back on board the Straight Talk Express.
articles.abstract: After an uneasy start to his campaign, Senator John McCain is back on board the Straight Talk Express.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASON CITY, Iowa, March 15 — Senator John McCain of Arizona worked hard for years to make himself the all-but-inevitable 2008 Republican presidential nominee, assembling a formidable machine of advisers and contributors, repairing his relationship with the Bush White House and reaching out to conservatives long wary of his views.

articles.headline: China Backs Property Law, Buoying Middle Class
articles.snippet: Supporters hope the measure secures the legal foundation for private entrepreneurs and urban home owners.
articles.abstract: Supporters hope the measure secures the legal foundation for private entrepreneurs and urban home owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Friday, March 16 — After more than a quarter-century of market-oriented economic policies and record-setting growth, China on Friday enacted its first law to protect private property explicitly.

articles.headline: Risky Business Still Attracts Eager Lenders
articles.snippet: This may not be a good time to borrow money if you are a homeowner with a poor credit history, but it is a fine time if you are a company with such a problem.
articles.abstract: This may not be a good time to borrow money if you are a homeowner with a poor credit history, but it is a fine time if you are a company with such a problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the subprime mortgage market implodes, it is worth noting just how that is affecting all the other credit markets where risky loans were deemed perfectly rational.
